title: Colorblindness and an Extra X Chromosome

content.question:
Red-green color blindness in humans is caused by a recessive allele located on the <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> chromosome. Figure 1 shows the potential offspring of a female who is red-green color-blind and a male with full-color vision. All of the possible male offspring would be color-blind, and all of the possible female offspring would have full-color vision.

If during the production of male gametes an error in meiosis occurred, sperm containing both an <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and a <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> chromosome could be produced.

How would the extra chromosome affect the male offspring produced by the gamete?

choices.label: None of the potential offspring would be male, because the potentially male zygote would have two <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> chromosomes, and the <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> chromosome would be ignored.

The male offspring would all be red-green color-blind, because of interference from alleles on the <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> chromosome.

The male offspring would have full-color vision, because of the presence of the extra <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> chromosome.

There would be no change to the phenotypes of the possible offspring, because the extra <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> chromosome would not be active.

content.answer: The male offspring would have full-color vision, because of the presence of the extra <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> chromosome.
